Congratulations on tackling the aphid infestation successfully with neem oil spray! That's a great example of quick thinking and effective action.

It's fantastic that you're learning through trial and error, and also seeking out additional knowledge through workshops and other resources. Companion planting and making organic fertilizers are both valuable skills to have in your gardening toolkit.

Companion planting can be a game-changer in terms of reducing pests and diseases, and creating a more balanced ecosystem in your garden. By planting certain vegetables, herbs, or flowers together, you can repel pests, attract beneficial insects, and even improve soil health. For example, planting marigolds with tomatoes can help deter nematodes, while basil and mint can repel pests that target vegetables.

Making your own organic fertilizers is also a great way to reduce your environmental impact and create a more sustainable garden. Neem oil, which you've already used, is a great example of a natural pesticide that can be used to control a wide range of pests. Other organic fertilizers like compost tea, worm casting, and bokashi can provide essential nutrients to your plants while promoting healthy soil microbiology.

What inspired you to attend the gardening workshop, and what were some of the most valuable takeaways you got from it? Are you planning to implement any new techniques or strategies in your garden soon?

By the way, how's your basil plant doing after the aphid infestation? Has it recovered well, or are you taking any extra precautions to prevent future infestations?
